metadata.titleEn: A study on the prevalence and related factors of frailty and pre-frailty in the older population with diabetes in China: A national cross-sectional study
metadata.description: The data comes from the China Urban and Rural Elderly Population Sampling Survey (SSAPUR) conducted in 2015, which is a cross-sectional study involving a national representative sample of the elderly aged 60 and above from 31 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities directly under the Central Government in Chinese Mainland. Subjects with diabetes were included in the study. The frailty index (FI) is based on 33 latent defects and is used to classify individuals into three categories: robust, pre frail, or frail. The data survey was conducted from August 1, 2015 to August 31, 2015. The sampling is divided into four stages. The first stage is to allocate the sample size based on the proportion of the elderly population in each province/city/autonomous region in the country. Using 2853 districts (counties) from 31 provinces (cities, autonomous regions) in mainland China as the basic sampling unit, 466 districts (counties) were selected for questionnaire survey. In the second stage, using the total number of elderly people in each district (county) as auxiliary information, four townships (streets) were selected from each district (county) using the PPS sampling method. Stage 3: Using the total number of elderly people in each township (street) as auxiliary data, four village (neighborhood) committees were selected from each township (street) using the PPS sampling method. Stage 4: In the selected townships (streets), based on the list of elderly people reported before the survey, an equidistant sampling method is adopted to select 30 elderly people. The design sample size for this survey is 223680 people, with a sampling rate of approximately 1 in 1000. The actual number of samples collected is 224142 people.

background: Diabetes is one of the most common chronic non-communicable diseases among the older adults worldwide. The 2017 China Diabetes Prevalence Survey showed that the prevalence of diabetes in the older adults aged ≥ 60 years was 30.0%, and China has the largest number of older adults with diabetes in the world. Various acute and chronic complications caused by diabetes seriously affect the health status and quality of life of the older adults. Frailty, an emerging global health burden, is a common geriatric syndrome. A meta-analysis of 21 studies from Western high-income countries showed the prevalence of frailty among community-dwelling older adults ranges from 4 to 59%, with an average prevalence of 11%, the pooled prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty among community-dwelling older adults in China were 10 and 43%, respectively, leading to an increased risk of falls, disability, hospitalization, and death, as well as an independent predictor of higher healthcare expenditure among older adults. As populations age, diabetes and frailty are frequently co-occurring health outcomes, and both frailty and diabetes increase the risk of adverse outcomes in older adults. A meta-analysis showed that older adults with diabetes with frailty had significantly increased risks of hospitalization, disability, and death compared with older adults with diabetes who were not frail. Studies have shown that frailty was an important factor affecting the target level of blood glucose management in the older adults with diabetes. The International Position Statement on Frailty in Diabetes emphasized that the identification and assessment of frailty should be part of the routine management of people with diabetes. Compared with developed countries, the research on frailty in the older adults in China started relatively recently, there were few comprehensive studies on the prevalence and associated factors of frailty and pre-frailty among older adults with diabetes nationwide.
research objective: To investigate the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty and its associated factors in Chinese older adults with diabetes through a nationwide cross-sectional study.
challenges: Our study has several limitations. First, the data on diabetes were self-reported and might be subject to memory bias. Second, this was a cross-sectional study, so the causal relationship between diabetes and frailty was not analyzed.
methods: The data were obtained from the Sample Survey of the Aged Population in Urban and Rural China (SSAPUR), conducted in 2015, which was a cross-sectional study involving a nationally representative sample of older adults aged 60 years or more from 31 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities in mainland China. Subjects with diabetes were included in this study. Frailty index (FI), based on 33 potential deficits, was used to categorize individuals as robust, pre-frail, or frail.
dataset: The data were obtained from the Sample Survey of the Aged Population in Urban and Rural China (SSAPUR), conducted in 2015, which was a cross-sectional study involving a nationally representative sample of older adults aged 60 years or more from 31 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities in mainland China.
findings: The weighted prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty in older adults with diabetes in China was 22.7% (95% CI 22.1–23.3%) and 58.5% (95% CI 57.8–59.2%), respectively, according to the weights created in our study. The prevalence of frailty in the older adults with diabetes was 22.4%, which was higher than that in the older adults without diabetes (8.2%; χ 2 = 3,884.9, P < 0.001). The prevalence of pre-frailty in the older adults with diabetes was 58.5%, which was higher than that in the older adults without diabetes (44.6%; χ2 = 1,284.3, P < 0.001). Our study also found that female, rural residency, illiterate, ethnic minority, widowed, living alone, financial difficulties, and very difficult medical reimbursement were associated with the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty in older adults with diabetes. Our study found significant regional differences in the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty in older adults with diabetes. The prevalence of frailty in older adults with diabetes in northern China was higher than that in southern China.

Definition.Question: What is a frailty index (FI) in the context of assessing older adults with diabetes?
Definition.Answer: A frailty index (FI) is a measure based on 33 potential deficits used to categorize older adults with diabetes as robust, pre-frail, or frail in a dataset involving a nationally representative sample in China.

Definition.Question: What is PPS sampling in the context of data collection for a cross-sectional study?
Definition.Answer: PPS sampling, or Probability Proportional to Size sampling, is a method used in data collection where the probability of selecting a sampling unit is proportional to its size, applied in a four-stage sampling process to select districts, towns, and villages in a nationwide cross-sectional study of older adults in China.

Definition.Question: What are the limitations of using self-reported data in research studies on diabetes among older adults?
Definition.Answer: Self-reported data in research studies on diabetes among older adults may be subject to memory bias, posing a challenge to the accuracy and reliability of the findings in a cross-sectional study context.

Interpretation.Question: How might the reliance on self-reported data impact the interpretation of diabetes prevalence and frailty status in older adults, and what steps could be taken to mitigate potential biases?
Interpretation.Answer: The reliance on self-reported data introduces the possibility of memory bias, which can affect the accuracy of reported diabetes prevalence and frailty status. To mitigate this, researchers could cross-verify self-reported data with medical records or use biomarkers to confirm diabetes diagnoses. Additionally, training interviewers to minimize inaccuracies during data collection could also help improve data reliability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to the choice of a four-stage sampling method in collecting data from older adults with diabetes across various regions in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The four-stage sampling method was chosen to ensure a nationally representative sample of older adults aged 60 years or more from 31 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities in mainland China. This method allowed for the proportional allocation of samples according to the elderly population distribution across these regions, enhancing the representativeness and generalizability of the findings to the entire older adult population in China.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might there be challenges in accurately identifying the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty in older adults with diabetes using cross-sectional data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in accurately identifying the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty may arise due to the reliance on self-reported data on diabetes, which could be subject to memory bias. Additionally, the cross-sectional nature of the data limits the ability to determine causal relationships between diabetes and frailty, potentially affecting the accuracy of prevalence estimations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What could cause regional differences in the prevalence of frailty among older adults with diabetes in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Regional differences in the prevalence of frailty among older adults with diabetes in China could be caused by varying socio-economic factors, healthcare access, and lifestyle practices across different regions. The study found that factors such as female gender, rural residency, illiteracy, ethnic minority status, widowhood, living alone, financial difficulties, and challenges with medical reimbursement were associated with higher prevalence, suggesting that these factors may contribute to regional disparities.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might self-reported data on diabetes influence the outcomes of a study investigating frailty prevalence, and what challenges could this present for data collection methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Self-reported data on diabetes can introduce memory bias, potentially affecting the accuracy of the outcomes regarding frailty prevalence. This challenge can complicate the reliability of data collection methods, as it may not accurately reflect the true prevalence of diabetes among the study population.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind conducting a nationwide cross-sectional study on frailty and pre-frailty among older adults with diabetes in China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to investigate the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty and its associated factors in Chinese older adults with diabetes through a nationwide cross-sectional study.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to include a frailty index based on 33 potential deficits in categorizing individuals as robust, pre-frail, or frail?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Including a frailty index based on 33 potential deficits is crucial because it helps in categorizing individuals accurately as robust, pre-frail, or frail, which is essential for understanding the health status and risks associated with older adults with diabetes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivates the collection of data from a nationally representative sample of older adults aged 60 years or more across 31 provinces in China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The motivation for collecting data from a nationally representative sample is to ensure the study's findings are generalizable across the diverse population of older adults aged 60 years or more in China, enabling a comprehensive understanding of frailty and diabetes prevalence and associated factors.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in sampling and categorizing older adults into robust, pre-frail, or frail categories in a nationwide study?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The categorization is based on a frailty index (FI) derived from 33 potential deficits. The sampling is conducted in four stages using a cross-sectional approach, with proportional allocation of samples based on the older population in each province, and PPS sampling methods at district, town, and village levels.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological challenges might be encountered when relying on self-reported data for assessing diabetes status in older adults?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges include potential memory bias due to the self-reported nature of diabetes data, which can affect the accuracy and reliability of the information. This limitation highlights the need for cautious interpretation of the relationship between diabetes and frailty.

Enablement.Question: What sampling techniques enable the collection of a nationally representative dataset on frailty and diabetes prevalence among older adults in China?
Enablement.Answer: The sampling techniques involved a four-stage process, where the first stage allocated sample numbers based on the proportion of the older population in each province. The second stage used PPS sampling to select districts, the third stage used PPS sampling to select towns, and the fourth stage used systematic sampling to select 30 older adults from each town.

Enablement.Question: How do self-reported data collection methods affect the accuracy of diabetes prevalence studies among older adults?
Enablement.Answer: Self-reported data collection methods might be subject to memory bias, which can affect the accuracy of diabetes prevalence studies by potentially underreporting or misreporting conditions.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection methods for assessing frailty and pre-frailty in older adults with diabetes face challenges in ensuring accurate self-reported diabetes data?
Expectation.Answer: Data on diabetes were self-reported and might be subject to memory bias, which can affect the accuracy of the information collected.

Expectation.Question: Why might a cross-sectional data collection method be limited in analyzing the causal relationships between diabetes and frailty among older adults?
Expectation.Answer: The cross-sectional nature of the study means that it cannot establish causal relationships between diabetes and frailty, as it captures data at a single point in time rather than over a longitudinal period.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the challenges faced in collecting reliable data on frailty and pre-frailty among older adults with diabetes, and how might these challenges impact the findings?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges in collecting reliable data include the reliance on self-reported information, which may be subject to memory bias, and the cross-sectional nature of the study, which limits the ability to establish causal relationships between diabetes and frailty. These challenges could impact the findings by potentially skewing the prevalence rates and not fully capturing the dynamic nature of frailty development over time.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges that might affect the accuracy of self-reported diabetes data in older adults.
Assertion.Answer: One challenge affecting the accuracy of self-reported diabetes data is memory bias, as older adults might not accurately recall their medical conditions, leading to potential inaccuracies in the data.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the frailty index is constructed and used to categorize older adults with diabetes into different frailty levels.
Assertion.Answer: The frailty index is based on 33 potential deficits and is used to categorize individuals into robust, pre-frail, or frail categories. This method helps in assessing the health status of older adults with diabetes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the data collection methods employed for gathering information on frailty and its associated factors in older adults with diabetes and suggest potential improvements for future studies.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection method involved a nationwide cross-sectional study utilizing a representative sample of older adults aged 60 years or more from 31 provinces in China. The sampling process was conducted in four stages, with the use of PPS sampling methods and equidistant sampling techniques. While this method provides a comprehensive representation, future improvements could include ensuring the verification of self-reported diabetes status to reduce memory bias and incorporating longitudinal data to assess causal relationships between diabetes and frailty.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential sources or strategies for expanding datasets on frailty and diabetes in the elderly population in China.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential sources for dataset expansion could include integrating data from electronic health records, collaborating with local health bureaus for more detailed patient histories, and incorporating wearable health technology data to gain continuous health monitoring insights. Strategies could involve increasing the sample size by including more diverse regions or sub-populations, and employing mixed-method approaches to capture qualitative data on lifestyle and socio-economic factors influencing frailty and diabetes.
